title: Srimad Bhagavatam 3.17.5 | HG Suvyakta Narsimha Dasa
speaker: HG Suvyakta Narasimha Dasa

segments.key_quote: Reading from Srimad Bhagavatam, Canto 3, Chapter 17, Text No. 5
segments.summary: The speaker begins the lecture by chanting mantras and announcing the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam that will be discussed.

segments.key_quote: unmolayan nagapateen vātyāṇīko rajo dhvajaḥ
segments.summary: The speaker chants the verse multiple times and then pronounces each word separately.

segments.key_quote: When there are natural disturbances like blowing cyclones, too much heat or snowfall and uprooting of trees by hurricanes, it is to be understood that the demoniac population is increasing and so the natural disturbance is increasing.
segments.summary: The speaker reads the translation and purport of the verse, explaining that natural disturbances are a sign of increasing demoniac influence.

segments.key_quote: There are many omens that were manifest when Jaya and Vijaya came down as Hiranyasha and Hiranyakashipu.
segments.summary: The speaker chants prayers and explains that the chapter discusses the omens that appeared when Jaya and Vijaya descended as demons.

segments.key_quote: But the kind of breezes that started blowing when Hiranyakashipu and Hiranyakashipu appeared, they were Suddhusvarsha and they were Phutkaaraan Eerein.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the breeze that blew at the time of the demons' birth was unpleasant and hissing, unlike the pleasant breeze of Chennai.

segments.key_quote: As soon as I got out of the car, I immediately got back inside.
segments.summary: The speaker shares a personal experience of arriving in Vrindavan in winter and being overwhelmed by the cold breeze.

segments.key_quote: And I was feeling somebody has set fire to my body.
segments.summary: The speaker shares a personal experience of the intense heat and unpleasant breeze during his first summer in Vrindavan.

segments.key_quote: When that becomes prominent in this material world, what happens is, all the entire system around which this whole material universe is designed gets disrupted.
segments.summary: The speaker connects the unpleasant breeze and other disturbances to the increasing demoniac influence and exploitation of material nature.

segments.key_quote: A pure breeze began to blow, pleasing the sense of touch, and bearing the aroma of flowers.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts the omens at the time of the demons' birth with the pure and fragrant breeze that blew when Krishna appeared.

segments.key_quote: The earth produces enough to satisfy the needs of a man, but not the greed of a man.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts modern cities with Vedic cities, emphasizing the importance of living in harmony with nature and avoiding greed.

segments.key_quote: Material nature also starts reacting.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that sinful activities lead to reactions from material nature, making the world an unbearable place to live.

segments.key_quote: This whole world has been in total turmoil.
segments.summary: The speaker describes the turmoil in the world and contrasts it with the steadiness present when the civilization is directed towards Krishna consciousness.

segments.key_quote: It is incumbent upon us, to live our life, free of sinful activities.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of living a life free of sinful activities to achieve peace and align with material nature.

segments.key_quote: Ultimate goal of life, in today's world is, money, money, money, sweeter than honey.
segments.summary: The speaker laments that the ultimate goal of life in the modern world is money and introduces the conversation between Chaitanya Mahaprabhu and Ramananda Raya about the true goal of life.

segments.key_quote: Following the Varna Ashrama system, is the way to satisfy Lord Vishnu, and satisfying Lord Vishnu, is the highest goal of life.
segments.summary: Ramananda Raya initially states that following Varna Ashrama Dharma is the way to satisfy Vishnu, which is the highest goal of life.

segments.key_quote: Give up all other kinds of Dharma, that means, this Varna Ashrama Dharma, and all these things, you give it up, and surrender unto Me.
segments.summary: Chaitanya Mahaprabhu rejects this, stating it is external, and Ramananda Raya quotes Bhagavad Gita 18.66 about surrendering to Krishna.

segments.key_quote: Simply renouncing the material duties, is not going to help one.
segments.summary: Chaitanya Mahaprabhu rejects this as well, as it lacks positive engagement, and Ramananda Raya suggests Jnana Misra Bhakti.

segments.key_quote: To hear Krishna's glories, being described by devotees, that is the highest goal.
segments.summary: Ramananda Raya quotes Lord Brahma from the Srimad Bhagavatam, stating that glorifying Krishna in the association of devotees is the highest goal, which Chaitanya Mahaprabhu accepts.

segments.key_quote: In Kali Yuga, the process of spiritual emancipation is, to glorify Krishna, in the association of other devotees.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of glorifying Krishna in the association of devotees (Satamprasangat) in Kali Yuga and explains why ISKCON and other institutions are necessary.

segments.key_quote: This is actually building up our spiritual strength.
segments.summary: The speaker describes Prabhupada's Sadhana program and how it builds spiritual strength to protect against Maya in Kali Yuga.

segments.key_quote: When distress comes in a person's life some people will see where distress comes they become very spiritually inclined others when they become distressed they'll become averse both kind of people you will see
segments.summary: The speaker answers a question about how distress can lead some people to spirituality while others become averse, explaining that it depends on whether a person is a Punyatma.

segments.key_quote: we'll stop here
segments.summary: The speaker concludes the lecture.
